Award.AwardTitle: LSS Postdoctoral Fellowship: Trust and Confidence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funds a postdoctoral fellow in interdisciplinary trust and confidence research. Public trust and confidence in governmental institutions is integral to democracy and necessary for effective and efficient governance. What does it mean, though, to say there is trust or distrust? The vast majority of studies and theories in trust and confidence are immersed only in one discipline, often ignoring contributions from other social sciences. This proposal funds a postdoctoral fellow, who could come from any social scientific discipline, to join an interdisciplinary team dedicated to developing and testing a comprehensive, multi-stage, interdisciplinary theory of trust and confidence in governmental institutions. The fellow will conduct relevant research and also bring together additional, interdisciplinary researchers interested in advancing trust/confidence research and theory. The interdisciplinary research is being conducted in a variety of settings and contexts where the findings will have practical implications: courts, law enforcement, municipal government, water regulation and natural resource management agencies, and science, including nanotechnology and agricultural biotechnology.

Measurement of trust and confidence and its relationship to knowledge about governing institutions is extremely important to the governing institutions the research team engages. The team has been communicating results of their research to the community organizations; the postdoctoral fellow will be closely involved in coordinating information sharing with governing institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major outcomes of this postdoctoral fellowship award fall into two broad themes. First, the fellowship resulted in the professional development of two researchers, namely, Tess M.S. Neal and Ellie Shockley. They now have successfully launched their careers. Second, the fellowship resulted in the scholarly products (such as books, articles, presentations, workshops, etc.) of Drs. Neal and Shockley and their collaborators. These products are available to a wide audience and have implications for both theoretical knowledge and real-world application.

 

Drs. Neal and Shockley used the fellowship to present their research, theoretical work, and research methods, and to moderate/chair panels at multiple conferences and other contexts. One such context was the Workshop on Institutional Trust and Confidence, organized by Drs. Neal and Shockley. These fellows also produced various publications, including but not limited to the book “Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Trust: Towards Theoretical and Methodological Integration.”

 

Altogether, Drs. Neal and Shockley have advanced interdisciplinary research on trust in institutions and organizational contexts and have embarked on research careers due to their fellowship experiences. Dr. Neal is a tenure-track assistant professor serving the Arizona State University New College of Interdisciplinary Arts & Sciences. Dr. Shockley is a research analyst serving Bismarck State College and the North Dakota University System.

 

Intellectual Merit: Trust in institutions is critical to governing and the functioning of organizations, courts and judicial systems, and so on. Despite so many disciplines studying trust-related issues and influencing trust-related policies, there is relatively little in the development of an integrated framework of institutional trust and confidence. Drs. Neal and Shockley’s fellowship involved building bridges between multiple research areas, culminating ultimately in integrative trust theorizing and measurement. Thus, an important outcome of this fellowship award is the extension of the work of researchers who have focused on measuring trust, confidence, and perceived legitimacy and justice. By bringing together insights from diverse researchers, Drs. Neal and Shockley have advanced knowledge on trust and confidence, ultimately contributing to areas of social science and furthering the goal of an integrated understanding of trust.

 

Broader Impacts:  Lack of trust in government has been a source of frustration across the political spectrum, and officials often seek to regain public trust in various institutions. Relatedly, in business, enhancing trust is core to success. Thus, the outcome of better understanding trust, due to this award, can assist society in significant ways. Drs. Neal and Shockley will continue influencing institutions and organizations through their academic and applied research and their service in judicial and governmental capacities.
